courses.description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Spanish to explore the basic features of the Spanish language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Spanish through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Spanish grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SPAN2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051,4001 or 4002
courses.learning_outcomes:
Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type. Can introduce and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has. Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.
- Listening: Can understand familiar words and very basic phrases concerning him/herself, his/her family and immediate concrete surroundings when people speak slowly and clearly.
- Reading: Can understand familiar names, words and very simple sentences, for example on notices and posters or in catalogues.
- Spoken interaction: Can interact in a simple way provided the other person is prepared to repeat or rephrase things at a slower rate of speech and help me formulate what he/she is trying to say. He/she can ask and answer simple questions in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- Spoken production: Can use simple phrases and sentences to describe where he/she lives and people he/she knows.
- Writing: Can write a short, simple postcard, for example sending holiday greetings. Can fill in forms with personal details, for example entering his/her name, nationality and address on a hotel registration form.
courses.course_syllabus:
| ***Course Content:*** The course will cover 5 lessons of the textbook -¡Nos vemos! 1. | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ***Chapter*** | ***Communicative situations*** | ***Grammar*** | ***Culture*** |
| ***Chapter 1*** *El viaje al español* (A journey into the Spanish language) | * Introduction * Greetings * Asking about the name. * Asking about unknown words. | * Stress rules. * Defined article. * Gender of the nouns. * The plural form of the nouns. * Subject pronouns. * Regular verbs –AR. * Numbers: 0- 10 | * Some famous people. * Most common Spanish names and family names. * The formal and informal ¨you¨. * The origin of the Spanish words. |
| ***Chapter 2*** *Primeros contactos* (First contacts) | * Introducing oneself. * Talking about my country. * Talking about physical state. * Spelling. * Asking about contact information. * Talking about work. * Negating. | * Present tense of SER. * Present tense of TENER. * The Spanish alphabet. * Regular verbs: -ER, -IR. * Undefined article. * Interrogative pronouns: CÓMO, QUÉ, DÓNDE, DE DÓNDE. * Negation. | * Work in Spain. * What to talk about on the first meeting? * Mexico. |
| ***Chapter 3*** *Mi gente* *(*My people*)* | * Family. * Describing people. * Date and months. * Age and birthday. * Talking about things that you like. | * Numbers from 11 to 100. * Possessive articles. * Adjective and noun agreement. * Present tense of ESTAR. * Interrogative pronouns: QUIÉN, QUIÉNES, CUÁNTOS, CUÁNTAS. * Me gusta/n… | * A family enterprise: Chocolates Valor. * Spanish familys. * Spanish singers. * Guatemala, El Salvador,Honduras. |
| ***Chapter 4*** *Mirador* (Review) | * Cultural similarities and differences. * Self evaluation: Theory and practice. * Learning to study. * Talk and play. | | |
| ***Chapter 5*** *Es la hora de comer* (It´s time to eat) | * Going to the supermarket. * Quantity and packing. * Talking about preference. * Ordering food. | * Irregular verbs: E:IE, O:UE. * Frequency adverbs. * Numbers: from a 100. * Object pronoun: direct object. * Impersonal construction: SE+verb. | * Christmas. * Typical Spanish food. * Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panamá. |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: First Step in Spanish
courses.description:
[This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]

This online self-directed learning course invites students without prior knowledge of Spanish to explore the basic features of the Spanish language and briefly introduces them to the Hispanic world through a virtual journey. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Spanish through interactive tasks and online exercises. They will learn some survival phrases in Spanish and cover some Hispanic cultural topics. This course serves as a taster for students who might consider taking Spanish courses in CUHK in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken SPAN1000,2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051,4001or4002
From 2023-24, students can only earn up to 2 units of these courses: CLCP1001,CLCP1101,CLCC1001,CLCC1101,JASP1350,HKSL1001,SPAN1001,GERM1001,KORE1001,FREN1001
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
- understand and use basic Spanish expressions.
- introduce themselves.
- understand very basic phrases when people speak slowly and clearly in Spanish.
- read and understand familiar words and very simple sentences.
- ask and answer simple questions on specific topics.
- write short simple texts and fill in forms with personal details.
- recognise the Hispanic cultural diversity.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Course Content: it will cover units of the online KEEP course.** | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Units | Speech Acts | Grammar | Culture |
| **Unit 1** *Spanish in the world* | - Introducing Spanish speaking countries. - Pronouncing and spelling simple words - Repeating slang expressions of Spanish speaking countries. - Saying YES and NO. | - The 3rd singular person of the present tense of the verb SER. - Yes (“Sí”) and No (“No”). - The Spanish alphabet. | - Spanish language facts. - Slang Hispanic expressions - Hispanic countries |
| **Unit 2** *Introducing yourself* | - Greeting people. - Introducing yourself with “ME LLAMO”. - Saying some personal information (e.g., telephone number, place of origin, etc.) | - The first, second and third singular persons of the verb LLAMARSE. - The first, second and third singular persons of the present tense of SER. - The numbers from 0 to 10. - Interrogative pronouns CÓMO, CUÁL, etc. | - Famous Hispanic people. - Spanish names and surnames. |
| **Unit 3** *Let’s discover Hispanic food!* | - Ordering food and drinks - Asking for prices - Saying it is expensive or cheap. | - Interrogative pronouns: CUÁNTO, QUÉ, etc. - The present tense of SER. | - Typical Hispanic food (paella, tapas, tacos, ceviche, etc.) - Tapas bar hopping. - Hispanic markets. |
| **Unit 4** *I like and I don’t like!* | - Expressing likes and dislikes - Referring to books, arts, movies, music, etc. | - Verb GUSTAR: ME GUSTA/N… and NO ME GUSTA. - Definite articles. - Masculine and feminine forms of nouns. - Negation in Spanish. | - Hispanic music - Hispanic cinema - Famous sports personalities |
| **REVIEW** | Self-evaluation: theory and practice. | | |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Civilization and Its Languages I
courses.description: This course offers a broad interdisciplinary introduction to the Hispanic civilization. It surveys the realities of Hispanic cultures and societies through the examination of their evolution, geography, languages, economy, social configurations, artistic ways of expressions, gastronomy, forms of leisure and celebrations. It attempts to foster a general understanding of the connections and the differences of Hispanic cultures and societies geographically separated widely apart. The course is taught in an interactive manner which engages students in classroom discussions and projects related to Hispanic issues of their interest. No prior knowledge in Spanish is required.
courses.learning_outcomes: The aim of this course is to let students explore different aspects of these cultures and societies and expose them to diverse beliefs, social realities, backgrounds and attitudes, while comparing with Hong Kong and Chinese customs and traditions. It is important to remark that only 40 million of speakers out of 400 live in Spain, being Latin America the place with more native Spanish speakers in the world. Although the course can not cover all aspects, it will give students an idea about culture, politics, clothing, food, history, music, art, climate, landscapes, economy and literature. The objective is to stimulate students’ thinking about these cultures as well as their own in order to broaden their horizon and bring them the opportunity to increase their knowledge about these cultures and countries. At the end of the course students should be able to have a deeper understanding of these Spanish speaking countries.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Presentation of the course (principles of the course; assessment scheme; time management; schedule for presentations; questionnaires)
• Clichés/stereotypes about Latin America, Spain
and Chinese people (brainstorming). Spanish in the world.
• Image of Spain in the world. Language policy: Spanish as the official language
• Present and discuss in class information about Spain.
• General facts. Review of its history, folklore, politics, literature and modern society.
• Image of Latin America.
• Present and discuss in class information about the countries of Central America.
Countries: Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panamá
• Present and discuss information about the Spanish Speaking countries of the Caribbean
Countries: Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico and Cuba
• Information and in class discussion about the countries of South America
• Countries: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, Venezuela.
• FINAL PROJECT

Texts:
The Cambridge Companion to Modern Latin American Culture by John King (Cambridge University Press)
Synopsis: Specially-commissioned essays analyze Latin American history, politics, art and literature from the nineteenth century to the present and reveal the common heritage of pre-Columbian and colonial Latin America. Although the Portuguese and Spanish-speaking states created in the early 1820s differed greatly geographically and demographically (in ethnic composition and economic resources), they also shared distinct historical and cultural traits. A chronology and guide to further reading make this volume an invaluable introduction to the rich and varied culture of modern Latin America.

Spain: A History by Raymond Carr (Oxford University Press)
Synopsis: In this up-to-date and engaging tour of Spain through the ages, one of the world's leading authorities on the history of Spain, Sir Raymond Carr, provides an authoritative overview of a country that has played a vital role in the history of the Western world. He tells of prehistoric Spain and of the imposition of Roman rule, which created the idea of Hispania as a single entity. There are knowledgeable discussions of the Visigoth monarchy, Moorish Spain, the establishment of an empire, and the eighteenth-century Enlightenment. Carr examines not only the political and economic development of Spain, but also the extraordinary artistic and literary achievements of the Spanish people. He charts the rise and fall of liberalism in the nineteenth century, and the subsequent period of political instability culminating in the Civil War and authoritarian rule. The book concludes with a look at modern Spain as a fully integrated and enthusiastic member of the European community. Attractively illustrated throughout, Spain: A History is the best historical account of Spain currently available for general readers.

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Civilization and Its Languages II
courses.description: Continuation of SPAN1101.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. demonstrate understanding of the key features of the Latin American cultures.

2. be familiar with the main Latin American cultural referents.

3. be able to interpret more critically materials, subjects, and real-world situations related to the Latin American world.

4. increase their cross-cultural awareness of Spanish speaking societies.

5. meaningfully assess differences between individuals and groups of people without resorting to stereotypes.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Latin American indigenous cultures

2 The Spanish colonization

3 The Multiethnic identities

4 Latin American varieties of Spanish

5 Revolutions and Independence

6 Latin American art

7 Latin American cuisine

8 The most influential Latin Americans

9 Present-day social, economical and political challenges

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish II
courses.description: Building on the knowledge acquired in SPAN1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Spanish in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Spanish culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Spanish while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken SPAN2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051,4001 or 4002
2. Prerequisite: SPAN1000
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:
1. Be able to confidently distinguish Spanish sounds and pronounce them in a way that other Spanish speakers will be able to understand
2. Have acquired a core active vocabulary of Spanish of over 300 words
3. Have improved the skills to make accurate predictions on the meaning of words and sentences through the context or their cognates in other languages known
4. Have reviewed the previously studied grammar points and expanded the basic intuitions on the Spanish morphology and syntax and reviewed and fixed already learnt basic grammar patterns
5. Be able to produce and understand simple messages in Spanish and interactively communicate in certain social situations with a basic awareness of the pragmatic rules involved
6. Be able to write simple compositions in Spanish (description, narrative, dialogue and letter form)

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish III
courses.description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Sounds of Spanish
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the phonetic system of the Spanish language, with an emphasis on the similarities and differences of pronunciation of Spanish and other languages. Illustrations and examples will be taken from modern spoken Spanish. Students learning Spanish are encouraged to take this course.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction.

2. Pauses and intonation groups.

3. Intonation.

4. Stress.

5. Vowels.

6. Diphthongs.

7. Syllable.

8. Consonants.

9. Writing system, sounds and transcription.

10. Varieties of Spanish.

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish I & II
courses.description: (Please read the Study Scheme Note.) This is a summer intensive Spanish language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of SPAN1000 and 2000.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SPAN1000,2000,2001,3000,3001,3002,3050,3051,4001 or 4002
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. be able to confidently distinguish Spanish sounds and pronounce them in a way that other Spanish speakers will be able to understand

2. have acquired a core active vocabulary of Spanish of over 300 words

3. have improved the skills to make accurate predictions on the meaning of words and sentences through the context or their cognates in other languages known

4. have reviewed the previously studied grammar points and expanded the basic intuitions on the Spanish morphology and syntax and reviewed and fixed already learnt basic grammar patterns

5. be able to produce and understand simple messages in Spanish and interactively communicate in certain social situations with a basic awareness of the pragmatic rules involved

6. be able to write simple compositions in Spanish (description, narrative, dialogue and letter / email form)
courses.course_syllabus:
SPAN2050

| Course Content: The course will cover 5 lessons of the textbook ‐¡Nos vemos! 1. |
| --- |
| Chapter | Communicative situations | Grammar | Culture |
| Chapter 1 El viaje al español (A journey into the Spanish language) | ‐ Introduction ‐ Greetings ‐ Asking about the name. ‐ Asking about unknown words. | ‐ Stress rules. ‐ Defined article. ‐ Gender of the nouns. ‐ The plural form of the nouns. ‐ Subject pronouns. ‐ Regular verbs –AR. ‐ Numbers: 0‐ 10 | ‐ Some famous people. ‐ Most common Spanish names and family names. ‐ The formal and informal ¨you¨. ‐ The origin of the Spanish words. |
| Chapter 2 Primeros contactos (First contacts) | ‐ Introducing oneself. ‐ Talking about my country. ‐ Talking about physical state. ‐ Spelling. ‐ Asking about contact information. ‐ Talking about work. ‐ Negating. | ‐ Present tense of SER. ‐ Present tense of TENER. ‐ The Spanish alphabet. ‐ Regular verbs: ‐ER, ‐IR. ‐ Undefined article. ‐ Interrogative pronouns 1. ‐ Negation. | ‐ Work in Spain. ‐ What to talk about on the first meeting? ‐ Mexico. |
| Chapter 3 Mi gente (My people) | ‐ Family. ‐ Describing people. ‐ Date and months. ‐ Age and birthday. ‐ Talking about things that you like. | ‐ Numbers from 11 to 100. ‐ Possessive articles. ‐ Adjective and noun agreement. ‐ Present tense of ESTAR. ‐ Interrogative pronouns 2. ‐ Me gusta/n… | ‐ A family enterprise: Chocolates Valor. ‐ Spanish familys. ‐ Spanish singers. ‐ Guatemala, El Salvador,Honduras. |
| Chapter 4 Mirador (Review) | ‐ Cultural similarities and differences. ‐ Self evaluation: Theory and practice. ‐ Learning to study. ‐ Talk and play. |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Hispanic Cinema
courses.description: This course explores the history and aesthetic qualities, as well as cultural and social aspects of cinema in the Spanish speaking world. It is designed to provide students with a basic knowledge of the cinematographic scene in the Hispanic world, with special attention to the films made in Spain, Cuba, Mexico and Argentina. It should also enable students to 'read' those films as both reflections on and critiques of Hispanic society and culture, and as part of a global world. This course is designed for students who are interested in exploring the growing international popularity of Hispanic. All films are with English subtitles. No knowledge of Spanish is required. Screening of movies will take place outside the class.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. Be able to distinguish several concepts related to Spanish Speaking countries.

2. Be able to recognize several concepts related to film.

3. Be able to analyze film scenes using tools learned during the term.

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Hispanic Media

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408

courses.description: This course explores the realms of cinema, television, music, dance, fashion, and cultural trends in Spain and Latin America. Students will gain insight into diverse aspects of Hispanic culture and acquire the necessary vocabulary to discuss these topics. Through engaging discussions, we analyze influential films, critically examine popular TV shows, explore music genres, appreciate dance forms, and delve into evolving fashion trends. This course offers a captivating journey into the vibrant world of Hispanic media and pop culture, expanding cultural horizons while enhancing language skills.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
- Develop a comprehensive understanding of Hispanic media and pop culture.
- Use vocabulary related to cinema, television, music, dance, fashion, and cultural trends in Spanish.
- Critically analyze influential films and popular television shows.
- Explore diverse music genres and their cultural significance.
- Appreciate the art of dance and its roles in Hispanic cultures.
- Examine the ever-evolving fashion trends and their impact.
- Gain insights into cultural differences and similarities between different countries.
- Enhance language skills through engaging discussions and interactions centered around Hispanic media and pop culture.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Course syllabus** | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Unit** | **Topics** | **Contents** |
| **Unit 1** | **Television and Advertisement** | * The history of television shows in Spain and its socio-political context in the 20th century * Television shows during the dictatorship and transition to democracy: themes and censorship * Main TV series in Spanish * *Telenovelas* (Soap operas): The characteristics and examples * The analysis of advertisement during the 20th Century * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about TV and advertisements.** |
| **Unit 2** | **Cinema** | * The history of Hispanic cinema: Major film directors, influential films, main genres and themes * Film festivals in Hispanic countries * International recognition of Hispanic cinema * Contemporary trends in cinema and awards * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about cinema** |
| **Unit 3** | **Press and Social Media** | * Print media landscape in Spain: Major newspapers and magazines * The role of journalism in Spanish society * The evolution of its print media in the digital age * The influence of social media on news consumption * Fake news, memes, and media literacy in Spain * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about press and social media** |
| **Unit 4** | **Dances** | * Traditional Hispanic dances * Flamenco: The origins, characteristics, music and instruments * Ball competitions and dancing TV shows * Spanish regional dances and representation in the media * The history and cultural significance of dance in Spain * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about dances** |
| **Unit 5** | **Music** | * Traditional music genres in Spain (e.g., flamenco, copla) and Latin America (e.g., reggaeton, trap) * Influential musicians and bands * Music festivals in Spain * Regional music traditions in Spain * Hispanic music industry and its impact on society * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about music** |
| **Unit 6** | **Spanish Fashion Industry** | * An historical overview of Spanish fashion * Influential Spanish fashion designers * Fashion trends in Spain * Fashion industry in major Spanish cities (e.g., Barcelona, Madrid) * Spanish fashion brands and their global presence * **Vocabulary and phrases to talk about fashion** |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish IV

meetings.instructor: Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ
Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ
Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ
Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ

courses.description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Spanish. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken SPAN3001,3002,3050,3051,4001 or 4002
2. Prerequisite: SPAN2001
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:
1. have reviewed the previously studied grammar points and expanded the Spanish morphology and syntax and reviewed and fixed already learnt basic grammar patterns.
2. have mastered the Spanish sounds and confidently pronounce them
3. have acquired a core active vocabulary of Spanish of over 700 words
4. be able to interactively communicate in a wide number of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved be able to write compositions in Spanish using past, present and future tense in different registers and styles.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Course Content: The course will cover last lessons of the textbook ESPAÑOL ABC : lessons 21, 22, 23, 24, 25. | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Lesson | Speech acts | Grammar |
| **Lección 20** *Qué cara es la vida* (Food) | - Talking about eating habits - Habits - Daily life - Recipies | - Impersonal clauses - Imperative (review) - Pretérito perfecto (review) |
| ***Lección 21*** *Hicimos una excursión* (We did a trip) | - Likes and preferences - Asking permissions | - Irregular verbs in present tense: ***preferir, querer, gustar*** - Gerund: ***hablando*** - Present continous: ***estoy hablando*** |
| ***Lección 21 (II)*** *Hicimos una excursión* (We did a trip)) | - Talking about trips - Talking about past actions - Experiences evaluation | - Past tense: Pretérito indefinido: ***hablé, comí, viví*** - Superlative structure: ***lo mejor de viajar, lo peor de ir en bici…*** - Temporal clauses - Preposition (review) |
| ***Lección 22*** *¡Cuánto tiempo sin verte!* *(Long time no see you!)* | - Biography. - Talking about celebrities. | - Pretérito indefinido( regular and irregular) ***Fui, estuve, dije…*** - Indefinido + Perfecto |
| ***Lección 24*** *Mi infancia* *(Mi childhood)* | - Talking about past - Talking about habits in the past | - Pretérito Imperfecto. ***Hablaba, comía, vivía*** - Temporal clauses: ***Ya / Todavía*** |
| ***Lección 25*** *¿Quién es ella?* *(Who is she?)* | - Talking about the past - Fairy tales | - Pretérito perfecto + indefinido + imperfect working together |
| ***Lección OL*** *Siglo XXI* (21 Century) | - Talking about the future - Suppositions, hypothesis | - Future tense. ***Hablaré. Comeré. Viviré*** - Conditional clauses. ***Si llueve, me quedaré en casa*** |

meetings.instructor: Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ
Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ
Miss Maria Del Carmen JORDAN FERNANDEZ

courses.description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in Spanish with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Spanish-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken SPAN3002,3051,4001 or 4002
2. Prerequisite: SPAN3000 or 3050
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:
1. Improve their communication skills in Spanish: oral and written comprehension and social
interaction.
2. Increase their working vocabulary and their competence of Spanish Grammar
3. Be able to express themselves both individually and parts of a group in certain social
situations, as well as defend your opinion and show disagreement in a debating exercise
4. Be able to write compositions according to the level of knowledge of the Spanish language
acquired.
5. Be able to be comfortably make use of past, present and future tenses according to the
context.
6. Have a basic knowledge of some events and key people of the history in Spanish speaking countries
courses.course_syllabus:
| Course Content: The course will cover 6 lessons of the textbook Aula 3: lessons 1,2,3,4 and 5 | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Lesson | Speech acts | Grammar |
| *Lección 1* | Biographies. Daily activities and past experiences. | Present perfect tense, imperfect and indefinite |
| *Lección 2* | Impersonal phrases. | Adverbs and Modals |
| *Lección 3* | Strategies for daily communication. Talking on the phone, chatting, leaving messages, etc | Verbs of intention: to ask, to suggest (*preguntar, recomendar)*. |
| *Lección 4* | Writing a sinopsis of a film. Telling jokes. | Descriptions using present tense and summarizing a story. Using indirect and direct object pronouns. |
| *Lección 5* *Cosas cotidianas* *(Daily life)* | Stating opinions in favor and against. Evaluating situations. Proposing solutions. | Present subjunctive. Phrases I think that…: *me parece muy bien/ mal que* |
| *Lección 6* | Telling stories and showing interest on a theme. anecdotes. | Combining different verbal tenses. |

courses.title: Spanish VI
courses.description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Spanish language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of Spanish. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Spanish and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Spanish-speaking societies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Not for students who have taken SPAN3051,4001 or 4002
2. Prerequisite: SPAN3001
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. Have widely improved their competence of Spanish grammar and increased their working vocabulary.
2. Have improved their communication skills in Spanish (oral and written production and
comprehension) according to the needs of the social interaction involved.
3. Be able to apply the language and the contents learnt to real situations, using it to relate to, reflect on
and analyze past and current global issues involving the Spanish-speaking world.
4. Be able to reflect on strategic skills to satisfy the needs of communication in the foreign language and
to make their learning more autonomous and long-lasting.
5. Be familiar with the format of the official exam for proficiency of Spanish as a foreign language
(DELE).
courses.course_syllabus:
| Course Content: The course will cover 6 lessons of the textbook Aula 3: lessons 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10 | | |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Lesson | Speech acts | Grammar |
| *Lección 6* *The Tourist* | Telling anecdotes and showing interest on a theme. | Combining different verbal tenses in order to tell short stories and anecdotes. |
| *Lección 7* *Discussing different themes* | Express feelings and interests. Human relations and disagreements. | Verbs to state personal opinions : To like, to prefer, to dislike, etc. |
| *Lección 8* Designing a system or an object to solve our daily life | Describing characteristics and functions. - Express opinions | Verbs of intention: to ask, to suggest (*preguntar, recomendar)*. - **Superlatives** - Modifier of adjectives - Exclamative sentences |
| *Lección 9* *Misteries.* | Organize a debate between scientists and esoteric fans. | Simple and Compound Future Tense. Constructions in subjunctive and indicative form. State personal hipothesis and tell mysterious anecdotes. |
| *Lección 10* *Good News !* | Pretend to be the Committee of an important Spanish Journal of the Media. | - Write news for a newspaper and comment it. Verbs related to transmitting info (to manifest, to declare) Vocabulary related to the Media. |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish through Film
courses.description: This course integrates language and content learning. It is based on a set of topics that will be introduced through the analysis of selected films. The course will approach these topics from both cultural and linguistic perspectives. This course aims to consolidate and extend students’ existing language skills, providing them with a solid understanding of Spanish culture. Special emphasis is placed on conversational fluency, grammatical accuracy and vocabulary acquisition. The course will be structured around 6 films which will provide the basis for various activities and debates that will help students develop their listening, speaking, writing, reading and interacting skills, as well as their ability to describe analyse, and reflect upon other cultural manifestations.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should have developed or improved their:

- Ability to communicate and participate in regular discussions on diverse topics.

- Capacity for close analysis of visual material and comparative analysis.

- Ability to describe, analyse and criticize diverse cultural manifestations.

- Ability to reflect upon their own learning process.

- Spanish language skills in the four language domains.
courses.course_syllabus:
Spanish Civil War. - Exploring relevant historical events

Work Art / Artists - Approaching the diversity of art. Historical events its consequences and its reflection in master pieces of art.

Migrations. - Cultural shocks. Adaptation to a new and foreign environment. Solitude. Generational conflicts. Homesickness. American dream.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
The evaluation process of the course will be conducted in the following manner:

a. 1 mid-term evaluation and collection of qualitative feedback from student panels/ forums/ internet forums

b. 1 end-of-term course evaluation with statistics and open comments from students regarding the course’s strengths and areas of improvements

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Conversation
courses.description: This course aims to enhance students’ oral communication skills in Spanish. Through selected student-oriented stimuli and topics related to social issues and contemporary affairs, students will practice the expression and exchange of personal views and ideas. Classroom activities may include in-class activities such as dialogue, role-play, narration, speech, group discussion, debate and multimedia activities. Emphasis will be placed on oral practice and an interactive learning environment with a view to helping students build confidence and develop fluency in using the language, to speak spontaneously in social interaction and acquire conversational techniques commonly used in a Spanish-speaking environment.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is designed to help the student strengthen and expand conversational skills.
The student will:
• Improve the ability to engage in oral discussion on basic themes and to respond appropriately in context-specific conversational settings.
• Expand and personalize the active vocabulary knowledge in common areas of conversation.
• Improve listening comprehension skills and further the ability to understand spoken language.
courses.course_syllabus:

| Unit 1 | Acting | *Pronunciation* * Intonation: perception and production. * Stress: perception and production. * Vowels and consonants: perception and production. | Oral text: Performance. Oral skill strategies 1 | * Spanish speaking short movies. |
| Unit 2 | Social movements | *Grammar*: * Speech connectors. *Vocabulary*: * Vocabulary related to social movements. *Communicative acts*: * Talk about social movements. | Oral text: Persuasive Monologue Oral skill strategies 2 | * Current political and socioeconomic situation of Spain. * 15-M movement. |
| Unit 3 | Gender | *Grammar*: * Present tense * Past tense *Vocabulary*: * Vocabulary related to gender. *Pronunciation*: * Intonation *Communicative acts*: * Talk about gender. | Oral text: Debate. Oral skill strategies 3 | * What is it to be a woman in Spain? What is it to be a man? * Women and men: Image, work and family. |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Business Spanish I
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce to students the genuine communicative situations in the setting of the Spanish-speaking business world. It aims at developing the basic language proficiency (speaking, listening, reading and writing) that enable one to confidently handle typical business transactions in Spanish. Students will be engaged in active practice. Role plays will be used to simulate a wide range of business situations. Specific features of Spanish business discourse will be put into practice. The course will also encourage learners to become more aware of the cultural factors in the business practices of Spanish-speaking countries, and the importance of improving the cross-cultural communication skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: SPAN2001,3000,3001 or 3050
Not for student who have taken SPAN3002,3051,4001 or 4002
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:
1. have attained and increased the basic functional Spanish language abilities in business contexts.
2. understand simple oral and written business messages in Spanish.
3. convey basic oral and written messages of business communications in Spanish.
4. be able to respond to a direct exchange of information on familiar and routine business matters in the target language.
5. demonstrate an increased awareness of the cultural traits of the Spanish-speaking world and the differences in intercultural business communications.
courses.course_syllabus:
SPAN3041

| ***Units*** | ***TOPICS*** |
| --- | --- |
| **Unit 1.** **CROSS- CULTURAL COMMUNICATION IN BUSINESS** | * First encounters. * Spanish business etiquette and cultural nuances. * Arranging a business meeting. * Describing your business. * Small talk: talking about interests and current issues. |
| **Unit 2.** **TALKING BUSINESS** | * Telephoning. * Setting an agenda. * Business travel. * Meetings. * Presenting products and projects. |
| **Unit 3.** **GETTING DOWN TO BUSINESS** | * Making comparisons. * Suggestions. * Justifying choices. * The expressions “seguro que”, “me imagino que”, “a lo mejor”, etc. * Verbs describing and naming business activities (ahorrar, invertir, etc). * Office supplies. |
| **Unit 4.** **BUSINESS WRITING** | * A job advertisement. * Writing a CV. * Letters of application, enquiry, complaint, etc. * Taking notes. * Report writing. * E-mails. * Writing a check. |
| **Unit 5.** **KEYS TO SUCCESS** | * Interviewing. * Preferences and needs. * Assessing performance. * Services and sales. * Using connectors (porque, debido a, en cambio, etc.). |

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish III & IV
courses.description: This is a summer intensive Spanish language course, covering the full syllabus of SPAN2001 and 3000.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken SPAN2001,3000,3001,3002,3051,4001 or 4002
2. Prerequisite: SPAN2000 or 2050
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should:

1. have reviewed the previously studied grammar points and expanded the intuitions on the Spanish morphology and syntax and reviewed and fixed already learnt basic grammar patterns

2. have mastered the Spanish sounds and confidently pronounce them in a way that other Spanish speakers will be able to understand

3. have acquired a core active vocabulary of Spanish of over 800 words

4. have improved the skills to make accurate predictions on the meaning of words and sentences through the context or their cognates in other languages known thus expanding the passive vocabulary

5. be able to interactively communicate in a wide number of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved

6. be able to write compositions in Spanish using past, present and future tense in different registers and styles.

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish V & VI
courses.description: This is a summer intensive Spanish language course, covering the full syllabus of SPAN3001 and 3002.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken SPAN3001,3002,4001 or 4002
Prerequisite: SPAN3000 or SPAN3050
courses.learning_outcomes:
In this course we will continue to combine practical-oriented work with grammar-focused. Creativity and team-work will be once more a fundamental part of our SPA courses as we expect students to achieve higher outcomes. By the end of the course, students should:

1. Have widely improved their competence of Spanish grammar and increased their working vocabulary.

2. Have improved their communication skills in Spanish (oral and written production and comprehension) according to the needs of the social interaction involved.

3. Be able to apply the language and the contents learnt to real situations, using it to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current global issues involving the Spanish-speaking world.

4. Be able to reflect on strategic skills to satisfy the needs of communication in the foreign language and to make their learning more autonomous and long-lasting.

5. Be familiar with the format of the official exam for proficiency of Spanish as a foreign language (DELE).
courses.course_syllabus:
SPAN3051

| Lecciones | Speech acts | Grammar and vocabulary |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Unidad 1. VOLVER A EMPEZAR (Starting anew) | - Talking about your personal background. - Telling anecdotes. - Describing your daily activities in the past tense. - Referring to actions. | - Review and practice of the simple past tense regular and irregular verbs. - The Present Perfect, the Imperfect and the Indefinite Past forms. - The verbal periphrasis: empezar a (start to), acabar de (*finish*), volver a (*to do something again*), dejar de (*stop doing something*), etc. |
| Unidad 2. PROHIBIDO PROHIBIR (Forbidden to forbid) | - Expressing obligations and prohibitions. - Constructing impersonal sentences. - Talking about habits. | - The modal verbs. - The impersonal constructions. - The Present Subjunctive. - Adverbial phrases: es normal (*normal*)/ habitual (*usual*)/ raro (*rare*), etc. - Quantifiers and expressions of quantity: todo el mundo (*everybody*)/ la mayoría (*the majority*)/ muchos (*many*) / algunos (*some*). |
| Unidad 3. MENSAJES (Messages) | - Conveying messages. - Applying communicative strategies to different situations. - Talking on the phone. - Taking and leaving messages. | - Reported speech and direct speech. - Clauses and reporting verbs (contestar, decir, explicar, preguntar, etc). - Verbs expressing intention: recomendar (*to recommend*), sugerir (*to suggest*), preguntar (*to* ask), insistir (to insist), etc. |

i

| Unidad 4. VA Y LE DICE… (Now go and tell…) | - Summarizing information and events. - Writing a film synopsis. - Telling jokes. . | - Review of the Present tense. - Direct and Indirect Object Pronouns. - The connectors. - Summarizing phrases. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Unidad 5. ¡BASTA YA! (Enough already!) | - Expressing wishes and needs. - Lodging complaints. - Assessing situations and events. | - The Present Subjunctive. - The subjunctive and the infinitive usages. |
| Unidad 6. EL TURISTA ACCIDENTAL (The accidental tourist) | - Telling anecdotes and stories. - Showing interest in a subject. - Expressing cause and effect. | - The combination of different verb tenses in oral and written discourse. - The pluperfect. - Expressions of preferences. - Travel vocabulary. - Positive and negative interjections. |
| Unidad 7. TENEMOS QUE HABLAR (We need to talk) | - Taking part in formal and informal conversations. - Expressing positive and negative feelings. - Showing interest and indifference. - Expressing opinion, agreement and disagreement. - Opposing views and defending arguments about issues in mini-debates. | - Sentence connectors: además (*furthermore*), entonces (*therefore*), de todas maneras (*anyway*), etc.) - Expressions for softening quarrels and misunderstandings, showing anger, saying positive comments, etc. - Key mini-debate jargon. |
| Unidad 9. MISTERIOS Y ENIGMAS (Mysteries and enigmas) | - Making hypotheses and conjectures. - Describing mysterious and supernatural events. - Expressing beliefs. | - Simple Future tense vs. Compound Future tense - Supernatural world vocabulary. - The different degrees of certainty. - The Indicative vs. the Subjunctive |
| Unidad 10. BUENAS NOTICIAS (Good news) | - Writing a news story - Delivering news. - Deciding who could participate in a reality show. | - The Conditional tense - The passive voice - Vocabulary related to mass media |
| OTHER ACTIVITIES | Spanish Film Festival |

courses.title: Spanish VII
courses.description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Spanish language courses. It aims at further developing students' ability to communicate in Spanish in various everyday situations. It also gives students a taste of Spanish culture and encourages them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice, students will be able to develop more confidence in interacting in Spanish while further expanding and enhancing their understanding of the grammar and pronunciation patterns.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: SPAN3002 or 3051
Not for students who have taken SPAN4002
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the student will be able to understand the main points of clear texts and in standard language that talk about issues that are known to himself/herself, whether they talk about work, study or leisure situations. He /she will know how to handle most of the situations that may arise during a trip through areas where the language is used. H/she is able to produce simple and coherent texts on topics that are familiar to him/her or in which he/she has a personal interest. The student will be able to describe experiences, events, wishes and aspirations, as well as briefly justify his/her opinions or explain his/her plans.
The student will develop a linguistic, pragmatic and sociolinguistic competence:
Linguistic competence: Knowledge of words and formal resources and ability to use them.
Pragmatic competence: Ability to recognize at an elementary level the principles according to which messages are organized and structured.
Sociolinguistic competence: ability to understand and produce adequate statements in different social contexts.
(¡Nos vemos! 3 Teacher’s manual)
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Lesson** | **Speech Acts** | **Grammar** | **Culture** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ***Chapter 1*** ***SIGO APRENDIENDO*** *I continue learning* | * Talking about learning experiences * School memories * Biography * Describe intercultural experiences | * Verbal periphrasis * Use of **desde, hace** * Past tenses review | * Day E in Instituto Cervantes * The actor Daniel Brühl * With taste: Coffee |
| ***Chapter 2*** ***¡BUEN VIAJE!*** Have a nice trip | * Advices and recommendations * Taking about wishes, likes and needs * Offer help * Making complains * Make agreements * Plan a trip | * Revising the Imperative form * Subjuntive to express desire and recommendations * Vocabulary about trip | * A scholar programme * The Quetzal route * With taste: Orange |
| ***Chapter 3*** ***MANERAS DE VIVIR*** Ways of living | * Talking about life styles * Talking about house chores * Transmit other people’s words * Introduce arguments and react * Opinions and oppose opinions * Talking about quality of life * Introduce a surprising information and react | * Direct and reported speech * Use of Indicative and subjunctive on direct and reported speech * Use of Indicative and subjunctive to express opinions and assessments * Use of **lo de** * Vocabulary of house | * The alternative village “Matavenero” * With taste: Potato |
| ***Chapter 4*** ***MIRADOR*** Review | * Talking about culture: Holidays in the Hispanic world * Self-evaluation. * Mistake therapy. * Leaning strategies. * Increasing vocabulary: A literary text to talk about. | | |
| **OTHER ACTIVITIES** | * Film festival: Students must choose to attend at least one of the 3 films that will be screened. (Dates to be confirmed by the teacher) | | |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.
courses.required_readings:
1. Lloret Ivorra et al. (2010). ¡Nos vemos! 3: Libro del alumno & Cuaderno de ejercicios (Textbook & Workbook), Barcelona: Difusión.
2. Handouts and PowerPoints provided by your instructor and available on Blackboard.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Complete Spanish grammar (2004) [electronic resource AVAILABLE AT CUHK ULS] / Gilda Nissenberg. New York: McGraw-Hill.
2. Modern Spanish grammar (2003) [electronic resource AVAILABLE AT CUHK ULS] a practical guide / Juan Kattán-Ibarra and Christopher J. Pountain. London: Routledge
3. Graded readings CU libraries have little books in Spanish that are adjusted to your reading levels (in Spanish we call them “lecturas graduadas”). Some e-books, downloadable via Internet that you can print or read comfortably in your computer, PDA, etc. The level varies from collection to collection, but initially you can try “nivel 1” (level 1) and progressively upgrade to another reading level if you feel you can manage it. To do a library search in ULS, type "lecturas graduadas" + "nivel 1" or "nivel 2" (+ "electronic"), etc.].

courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish VIII
courses.description: This course focuses on the further development of speaking, reading, listening and writing skills in Spanish with emphasis on conveying life experiences. It will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Spanish-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyse various types of texts.
courses.learning_outcomes:

He /she will know how to handle most of the situations that may arise during a trip through areas where the language is used. He is able to produce simple and coherent texts on topics that are familiar to him/her or in which he/she has a personal interest. The student will be able to describe experiences, events, wishes and aspirations, as well as briefly justify his/her opinions or explain his/her plans.
The student will develop a linguistic, pragmatic and sociolinguistic competence:
Linguistic competence: Knowledge of words and formal resources and ability to use them.

courses.course_syllabus:
| **Course Content:** *The course will cover 4 units of the textbook ¡Nos vemos! 3* | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **UNITS** | **Communicative situations** | **Grammar** | **Culture** |
| **5. ¿Papel o pantalla?** *Paper or screen?* | * To talk about reading habits and cinema likes. * To value a book or a movie. * To summarize one plot. * To make suppositions about the future. * To express impersonality. * To talk about ended events in the future. * To organize a text. | * The passive voice. * The passive voice reflexive: *se + third person.* * Review of the use of *estar* + perfect participle. * The connectors: sin embargo, sino también. * The review of the simple future. * The perfect future: forms and uses. * Vocabulary of the cinema and literature. | * The author: Rosa Ribas and her novel *Entre dos aguas*. * The corn. |
| **6. Con los cinco sentidos** *With the five senses.* | * To talk about the five senses. * To describe objects. * To express the reason, the end and the consequences. * To talk about the music. * To talk about likes and flavours. * To describe a dish. * To express impersonality. | * The verbs *oir* and *oler*. * The relative clauses with preposition. * The subjunctive with *para que, de modo que…* * Resources for expressing impersonality. * The vocabulary of the senses. | * Visits for blind people in the zoo of Buenos Aires. * Peruvian cuisine. * The wine. |
| **7. De todo corazón** *From the bottom of my heart.* | * To describe the physical appearance and the personality. * To speak about moods. * To talk about moods changes. * To express feelings and sensations. * To talk about relationships and personal conflicts. | * The uses of ser and estar with adjectives. * The relative clauses with indicative or subjunctive. * The vocabulary of feelings and values. | * Famous couples in the Hispanic world. * The saffron. |
| **8. Mirador** *Review* | * To talk about cultural issues: ways of speaking in the Hispanic world. * Self-evaluation. * Learning from mistakes. * Literary text: pieces of the novel *La tía Julia y el escribidor* by Vargas Llosa. | | |
